header_summary:
Maxim Orlovsky raises concerns about the quantum security of taproot wallets in Bitcoin, particularly highlighting the vulnerability when public keys are exposed, and the potential for quantum-powered manipulation of transactions. This skepticism challenges the perceived security of taproot script-path spending against quantum threats, urging the Bitcoin Development community to enhance security measures. [Read more](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/bee6b897379b9ae0c3d48f53d40a6d70fe7915f0.camel@real-or-random.org/T/#m672044ae46a076082179d96f90b29b038763ff2e)

Christopher Allen discusses Blockchain Commons' efforts to integrate FROST signing with Bitcoin transactions, aiming to improve resilience and efficiency in multisignature processes. The upcoming Gordian meeting will showcase a working demo, emphasizing the need for community engagement to address technical challenges and foster educational initiatives for broader adoption of FROST technology. [More details](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CACrqygC5925FrJ5WN=986Bni5+0zZ7YeC_EqAXyao=u5rK3P_A@mail.gmail.com/T/#u#m9cde5186fa3252c00d5051a72924b5931f416660)

Murch questions the feasibility and necessity of indefinitely retaining information on unconfirmed Bitcoin transactions, highlighting existing node mechanisms for transaction relay and evaluation. The discourse suggests that maintaining a permanent log of unconfirmed transactions may not be practical or beneficial, advocating for discussions on more suitable platforms like [Bitcoin Stack Exchange](https://bitcoin.stackexchange.com) for in-depth exploration of such technical matters.

Glozow proposes lowering Bitcoin Core's minimum relay feerate to address the relay and mining of transactions with fees below 1 sat/vB, considering recent trends and the need to balance block relay efficiency with protection against DoS attacks. This suggestion, part of a broader discussion on optimizing transaction cost and network resilience, invites further community input on setting appropriate feerates and their implications for the ecosystem. [Proposal details](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/changing-the-minimum-relay-feerate/1886)

recent_posts.title: Taproot is post-quantum secure when restricted to script-path spends
recent_posts.summary:
- Maxim Orlovsky raises quantum security concerns for taproot wallets.
- He suggests exposed public keys in wallet descriptors risk quantum attacks.
- Quantum miners or nodes could replace transactions, challenging taproot security.

recent_posts.title: [ann] FROST Signing for Bitcoin: Demo + Taproot Integration Discussion @ Aug 6 Gordian Call
recent_posts.summary:
- Blockchain Commons is leading with FROST signing to enhance Bitcoin's security and efficiency.
- A FROST demo will be presented at the Gordian meeting, aiming for community feedback on Taproot integration challenges.
- Educational initiatives and resources support developers in adopting FROST and BDK technologies for Bitcoin.

recent_posts.title: Proposal: Self-Verifiable Transaction Broadcast Log for Enhanced User Transparency
recent_posts.summary:
- Nodes have mechanisms for logging transaction activities, questioning indefinite data retention.
- The necessity of keeping records for unconfirmed transactions is debated given documentation challenges.
- Discussion on technical aspects of Bitcoin is suggested to be moved to specialized forums.

recent_posts.title: Changing the minimum relay feerate
recent_posts.summary:
- A proposal suggests lowering Bitcoin Core's relay fee from 1000 sat/kB to 100 sat/vB.
- The proposed change addresses transactions under 1 sat/vB and aims to improve block propagation.
- Discussion includes balancing relay fees to prevent DoS attacks and consider Bitcoin's price fluctuations.

recent_posts.title: Fingerprinting nodes via addr requests
recent_posts.summary:
- The proposal suggests randomizing GETADDR timestamps to 10 ± 2 days in the past.
- Concerns arise over creating synchronized patterns, risking addresses being marked 'Terrible'.
- This could filter out batches, challenging the network's address list diversity and robustness.

recent_posts.title: Where does the 33.33% threshold for selfish mining come from?
recent_posts.summary:
- Increasing block production in Bitcoin mining could distribute new BTC beyond projections.
- Transition to fee-based mining alters revenue dynamics, depending on transaction space and fee rates.
- The evolving mining landscape highlights the potential for non-inflationary transaction throughput manipulation.

active_posts.title: A Taproot-native (re-)bindable transaction bundle proposal
active_posts.summary:
- Greg Sanders and team proposed a Bitcoin infrastructure enhancement.
- They introduced `OP_TEMPLATEHASH` as an alternative to `OP_CHECKTEMPLATEVERIFY`.
- This proposal aims to simplify Bitcoin systems and improve capabilities.

active_posts.title: Make pathological transactions with more than 2500 legacy signature operations non-standard
active_posts.summary:
- The activation of BIP54 poses inherent risks due to 2500 invalid legacy sigops.
- To mitigate risks, a proposal suggests delaying BIP54 until the majority network agrees.
- Bitcoin Core PR 32521 aims to enhance network security by preventing potential DoS attacks.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Utreexo Nodes
active_posts.summary:
- Tadge Dryja, Davidson Souza, and Calvin Kim proposed three BIPs focusing on Utreexo.
- Utreexo enables transaction verification without the full UTXO set, improving blockchain efficiency.
- They seek community feedback on GitHub to refine these proposals for a scalable Bitcoin network.

active_posts.title: Changes to BIP-360 - Pay to Quantum Resistant Hash (P2QRH)
active_posts.summary:
- BIP-360 enhancements improve Bitcoin's quantum computing resilience by adopting a script-only Taproot approach.
- The modifications simplify implementation and increase protection against long-exposure quantum attacks.
- Future plans include separate development of Post-Quantum signatures, allowing for flexible integration.

active_posts.title: A simple backup scheme for wallet accounts
active_posts.summary:
- Josh's method introduces unique inscription and location features.
- The proposal suggests standardizing Salvatore's method, then adding Josh's unique aspects.
- A more comprehensive solution is sought by combining both methods' strengths.

active_posts.title: Fee-Based Spam Prevention For Lightning
active_posts.summary:
- Jager and Teinturier proposed fee protocols for the Lightning Network to reduce spam and inefficiency.
- Enhancements include payment confirmation secrets and burn outputs to secure fee allocation and encourage cooperation.
- The protocols define Upfront, Hold, and Success Fees to cover operational costs, compensate for delays, and reward successful payments.

today_in_history_posts.title: Improving JoinMarket's resistance to sybil attacks using fidelity bonds
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Fidelity bonds in bitcoin may lead to centralization and privacy concerns.
- Renting out fidelity bonds incurs costs similar to purchasing and locking bitcoins.
- The main goal of JoinMarket is to enhance privacy without compromising bitcoin's other properties.

today_in_history_posts.title: Trampoline Routing
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Trampoline routing enables deferred route calculation in the lightning network via trampoline nodes.
- Alice uses trampoline nodes to send payments, synchronizing fees and cltv requirements for reliability and ease of use.
- Trampoline fees and cltv can be exchanged using a gossip filters system, improving upon BIP37 without its drawbacks.

today_in_history_posts.title: Bolt 12 Trusted Contacts
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bolt 12 enhances lightning wallets with offers and contacts for simplified, authenticated transactions.
- It suggests a standard for selective identity revelation using `contact_key` for trusted interactions.
- Feedback is sought to refine [bLIP 42](https://github.com/lightning/blips/pull/42) for privacy-respecting, user-friendly payments.
